quote-source: Caitlin Flanagan, The Dark Power of Fraternities, The Atlantic, February 19, 2014.
quote-text: If they were old enough to die in Vietnam, powerful enough to overthrow a president, groovy enough to expand their minds with LSD and free love, then they certainly didn’t need their own collegesâthe very places where they were forming their radical, nation-changing ideasâto treat them like teenyboppers in need of a sock hop and a chaperone. It was a turning point: American colleges began to regard their students not as dependents whose private lives they must shape and monitor, but as adult consumers whose contract was solely for an education, not an upbringing.
